This is the second time since 1990 that the match was staged, after a planned resumption of the cup was cancelled in 2014. The game was played between [[Hapoel Be'er Sheva F.C.|Hapoel Be'er Sheva]], champions of the 2015–16 Israeli Premier League and [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]], winners of the 2015-16 Israeli State Cup. As it has ended with the score of 4-2 to [[Hapoel Be'er Sheva]] after they were losing to 2-0 in the half time. ==Match details== {{football box |date = 11 August 2016 |time = |team1 = [[Hapoel Be'er Sheva F.C.|Hapoel Be'er Sheva]] |score = 4–2 |penaltyscore= |report = |team2 = [[Maccabi Haifa F.C.|Maccabi Haifa]] |goals1 = [[Maor Buzaglo]] {{goal|54||69}}

{{For|the home ground of Liverpool F.C.|Anfield}} {{one source|date=January 2016}} {{use dmy dates|date=March 2012}} {{coord|56.110|-3.930|display=title|region:GB_scale:10000}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Annfield | nickname = | image = | location = [[Stirling]], Scotland | coordinates = | broke_ground = 1945 | opened = 1945 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 1993 | demolished = 1993 | owner = [[Stirling Albion F.C.]] (1945–81)
[[Stirling Council]] (1981–93) | surface = Natural Grass (1945–86)
Synthetic Surface (1986–93) | construction_cost = | architect = | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Stirling Albion F.C.]] (1946–92) | seating_capacity = | dimensions = }} '''Annfield Stadium''' was a football stadium in [[Stirling]], Scotland. The stadium was home to [[Stirling Albion F.C.]] until 1993 when it closed after Stirling Albion moved to [[Forthbank Stadium]]. ==History== Before [[World War II]], [[King's Park F.C.|King's Park]] was the [[Scottish Football League]] club based in Stirling, but their [[Forthbank Park]] ground was destroyed by the [[Luftwaffe]] during the war.{{harvnb|Inglis|1987|p=313}} Rather than resurrect King's Park, a group of local businessmen led by coal merchant Tom Fergusson, decided to purchase the Annfield Estate. They formed new club called [[Stirling Albion F.C.|Stirling Albion]]. Oak trees were cleared from the estate to lay a pitch and Albion trucks were used as viewing platforms until a stand was built. Annfield opened on 1 August 1945 and the first game played at Annfield was Stirling Albion's tie with [[Edinburgh City F.C.|Edinburgh City]] on 18 August 1945, Stirling Albion won the game 8–3. The club constructed a main east stand in 1946 and rebuilt three years later, while a west stand was built in the early 1950s. The record attendance of 26,400 was set by a [[1958–59 Scottish Cup]] tie against [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]]. Soon after this, the club erected a roof over the northern terracing. It installed floodlights in 1961 and inaugurated with a friendly match against [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] in November. During this period, the Annfield House provided the dressing rooms and club offices. In 1974, these functions moved to a new block erected behind the east stand. Stirling Albion sold Annfield to [[Stirling Council]] in 1981 when it was on the verge bankruptcy. The club's only choice to avoid insolvency was selling the ground for £250,000 to the council and then renting it for £3,000 per annum. In April 1984, the council conducted a safety assessment that resulted in condemnation of parts of the east stand. Stirling Council decided that it would only invest further public funds in Annfield if it were more accessible to the community. This resulted in the installation of a [[synthetic turf|synthetic pitch]], which the Scottish Football League approved in 1987. The first match in Scottish football history played on a synthetic surface was at Annfield in September 1987, between Stirling Albion and [[Ayr United F.C.|Ayr United]]. The Stirling Council spent significant funds on Annfield during the 1980s; £100,000 for new floodlights, barriers and gates in 1986 and £450,000 on the synthetic pitch. The cost of the pitch was relatively high because the sloped surface required leveling. The stadium added 600 plastic seats in the west stand in 1987, but the east stand was largely demolished resulting in a capacity of 14,000. Stirling Council decided in the early 1990s that Annfield should be replaced as the cost of upgrading the buildings and the pitch was not economical. The council constructed [[Forthbank Stadium]] and closed Annfield on 31 May 1993, at the end of the [[1992–93 in Scottish football|1992–93 season]] an after 48 years of use. It demolished the facility to make way for a new housing development. ==See also== * [[History of Scottish football#Stadium moves and refurbishments|Scottish stadium moves]] ==References== {{reflist}} ;Sources *{{cite book| ref=harv| first=Simon| last=Inglis| author-link=Simon Inglis| title=Football Grounds of Britain| date=14 May 1996| publisher=Collins Willow| isbn=978-0002184267}} {{Stirling Albion F.C.}} {{Football venues in Scotland}} [[Category:Defunct football venues in Scotland]] [[Category:Sports venues in Stirling (council area)]] [[Category:Stirling Albion F.C.]] [[Category:Demolished buildings and structures in Scotland]] [[Category:Scottish Football League venues]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1945]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 1993]] [[Category:Demolished sports venues in the United Kingdom]]

{{Basketball League of Serbia awards}} The '''BLS Super League MVP''', or '''Serbian Super League MVP''', is the award bestowed to the player that is deemed to be the "[[Most Valuable Player]]" during the second part of a season of the [[Basketball League of Serbia]]. The Basketball League of Serbia is the [[Serbian basketball league system|top-tier level national]] men's professional club basketball league in [[Serbia]]. The award has existed and been awarded by the Serbian League since the [[2006–07 Basketball League of Serbia|2006–07 season]].

A '''batting cage''' (or '''tunnel''') is an enclosed area for [[baseball]] or [[softball]] players to practice the skill of [[Batting (baseball)|batting]].
The optimal material for batting cages is netting, and they are typically rectangular in shape. [[Chain-link fence]] is not required but can be useful to enclose the netting to prevent vandalism. However, this material is not suitable for the primary impact layer because it will warp the fencing and damage balls. The ideal netting for a batting cage is either diamond- or square-shaped.<ref>{{cite web|title=What Is The Best Backyard Batting Cage|url=http://www.backyardbattingcages.net/best-backyard-batting-cage/|website=Backyard Batting Cages|accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref> Both types of netting have their advantages and disadvantages.
==Usage==
A [[Batter (baseball)|batter]] stands at one end of the cage, with a [[pitching machine]] (or, less often, a human [[pitcher]]) at the opposing end. The pitcher or pitching machine pitches baseballs to the batter, who hits them. It is recommended to use a protective pitcher's L-screen to prevent batted balls from striking the pitcher or machine.
The cage is used to keep the loose baseballs within a certain range so that they're easy to pick up and are not lost. Batting cages are found both indoors and outdoors.
The interior floor of a batting cage may be sloped, to automatically feed the baseballs back into the automatic pitching machine. The automatic pitching machines using sloped floors usually pitch out a synthetic baseball or softball, rather than an official solid core leather hardball.
Commercial batting cages pitch with several different speeds, which can range from {{convert|30|mi}} (for [[softball]]) to {{convert|90|mi}} per hour.
[[Cricket nets]] and tunnels, used by [[cricket]] [[Batsman (cricket)|batsmen]] are similar in purpose, but [[bowling machine]]s are much less common than facing a live [[Bowler (cricket)|bowler]] (this reflects the fact that nearly half of the members of a cricket team are specialist bowlers, and therefore proportionately more bowling practice is needed in cricket than pitching practice in baseball).
Netting can greatly vary in quality and durability. #21 Gauge is suitable for little-league players, #36 Gauge is suitable for High-School players, and #60 is recommended for Commercial facilities and Pro Players. Resources such as this [http://www.practicesports.com/playbook/netting-101-a-visual-guide-to-sports-netting/ Netting Infographic Guide] are helpful for identifying the best netting for an application.
==Types== ===Indoor=== Indoor batting cages are typically suspended by steel cable lines, 1 line every 6–8 feet. The anchor points being the most important component, typically connected using a steel plate to the wall. Without strong anchors, the netting will sag.
===Outdoor=== Outdoor batting cages are typically installed using steel pole sections (2 uprights and 1 cross-bar per section), spaced every 12–20 feet. The greater the span between supports, the more sag in the netting and less usable the cage becomes.<ref>{{cite web|last=Schneider|first=Chad|title=Batting Cage Getting Started Guide|url=http://www.practicesports.com/playbook/netting-getting-started-guide-what-kind-of-cage-system-do-i-need/|work=Practice Sports|publisher=Joe Stubler|accessdate=August 15, 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{Refimprove|date=July 2011}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Boothferry Park | image = Boothferry.jpg | caption = Boothferry Park in 2008 | location = [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]], [[East Riding of Yorkshire]], [[England]]| | broke_ground = | opened = 1946 | closed = 2002 (as a football stadium)
2007 (supermarket tenants) | demolished = 2008–2010 | owner = | operator = | surface = Grass | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Hull City A.F.C.|Hull City]] (1946–2002)
[[Grandways (supermarket)]] (1980s–early 1990s)
[[Kwik Save]] (1990s–2007)
[[Iceland (supermarket)|Iceland]] (1990s–2007) | seating_capacity = 15,160 | record_attendance = 55,019 – Hull City vs [[Manchester United]], February 1949 }} '''Boothferry Park''' was a [[Association football|football]] stadium in [[Kingston upon Hull|Hull]], England, which was home to [[Hull City A.F.C.]] from 1946 until 2002, when they moved to the [[KC Stadium|Kingston Communications Stadium]]. In later years, financial constraints forced Hull City to allow [[Kwik Save]] and [[Iceland (supermarket)|Iceland]] supermarkets to embed themselves into the stadium's structure.Photos at Tim's 92, http://tims92.blogspot.co.uk/2011/03/hull-city-boothferry-park-with-wolves.html {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304091645/http://tims92.blogspot.co.uk/2011/03/hull-city-boothferry-park-with-wolves.html |date=4 March 2016 }} Parts of the ground were demolished in early 2008, more than five years after the last game was played there, and the remainder in 2011. __TOC__ ==History== === The planning years === The ground was originally planned in 1929, and work began on the site from 1932 based near the [[Humber|Humber Estuary]]. Financial difficulties severely hampered this development, with the playing area and part of the [[Terrace (stadium)|terracing]] appearing over the following 12 months before work and progress ground to a halt. A proposal in 1939 for a sports stadium on the site was the catalyst for further development, as even though this threw up doubt for the original stadium plans, no suitable financial offer for the land was forthcoming, and instead the Hull City board enquired after, and were granted, a [[The Football Association|Football Association]] loan to the sum of £6,600. This meant the new ground would be ready for the opening of the 1941 season. The onset of the [[Second World War]] was to again frustrate the development of the football ground, as during the war, the ground was used by the [[British Home Guard|Home Guard]], and was, for a period, used to repair tanks. This, not unexpectedly, had an adverse effect on the playing area – following the end of the war, the pitch was in very poor shape and prone to waterlogging. Building materials were hard to come by in the post-war years for something as "frivolous" as a football stadium in the [[Hull Blitz|heavily bombed city]], this and the state of the pitch meant that the ground was still not in a usable state by the 1945–46 season, so the club was forced to return to playing its matches at one of its former homes, [[The Boulevard (stadium)|the Boulevard]], the then home of [[Hull F.C.|Hull rugby league club]], one of the city's two [[rugby league]] clubs. ===Opening and continued construction=== The ground was opened in August 1946, 17 years after its initial proposal, but only had planning permission for one stand along the west side with an upper cost limit of £17,000. The ground was still not fully completed and it became a race against time to make the stadium ready for its opening match against visiting [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]].{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Mike|title=A Century of City|year=2005|publisher=Yore Publications|isbn=0-9547830-7-7|page=49}} Twenty-thousand people gathered to watch the opening ceremony performed by the city's lord mayor. The teams were led onto the pitch by Sergeant JT "Tommy" Brooke riding a white horse. Sergeant Brooke was a detective and mounted officer in the Hull Police and was a veteran of the [[First World War]] and the [[Battle of the Somme]] where he was a machine gunner with the [[Royal Horse Guards]]. By 1948 the attendance record had swelled to 40,179 as the stadium hosted visitors [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] in the [[FA Cup]]. The terracing embankments were raised and by February 1949 a ground and club record which still stands was hit – 55,019 turned out to watch Hull City play [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]. The locally famous [[Boothferry Park Halt railway station|Boothferry Halt]] opened in 1951. The ground now had its own railway station, its first use being a fixture against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] when six trains ran the football service between [[Hull Paragon railway station|Paragon Station]], Hull's central railway station and Boothferry Park. At the same time, work proceeded on the covering of the North Stand. The East Terrace was the next to be covered, albeit with a [[temporary structure]]. This [[temporary structure]] was never replaced, and stood throughout the years of the ground. The popular East Terrace became known as the Kempton Stand after Kempton Road on the other side of the railway station. With the three stands completed, the ground was now suited to a floodlight installation. Two gantries housing 96 lamps were built, one on the west and one opposite on the east following a licence being granted. Although this lighting system was the envy of many clubs, advancements in stadium lighting came rapidly, and the system soon needed replacement. A six pylon system replaced the old gantries in 1963. [[File:Boothferry lights.JPG|thumb|right|Lights of Boothferry Park]] The new lights were used for the first time in 1964, using four of the six available, in an evening match against [[Barnsley F.C.|Barnsley]] which ended in a 7–0 win for the Tigers. In 1965 a new South Stand was built over the Bunker's Hill Terrace. The new two-tiered structure included a propped [[cantilever]] roof, 2,500 seats in the upper tier and terracing for 4,000 more in the lower tier. The new stand was arguably the best stand at Boothferry Park, and a reminder of the golden days in the declining years to come. [[File:Boothferry park last day.jpg|thumb|right|Celebrations taking place on the pitch on the last day that football was played before demolition]] On 20 March 1967, Boothferry Park hosted an [[FA Cup]] 2nd replay between [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] and [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]]. Over 40,000 fans attended and Leeds United won 2–1. It was standard procedure in the pre penalty shoot-out days for 2nd and subsequent replays to be held on neutral grounds. On 16 February 1972 Boothferry Park hosted a full international match between [[Northern Ireland national football team|Northern Ireland]] and [[Spain national football team|Spain]]. The result was drawn at 1–1.{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/matches/1972/02/16/europe/european-championships/northern-ireland/spain/627598/|title=Northern Ireland vs. Spain 1 – 1|accessdate=10 July 2011}} The final football match to be staged at Boothferry Park saw Hull City lose 0–1 to [[Darlington F. C.|Darlington]] in December 2002.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_3/2553217.stm|title=Hull 0–1 Darlington|date=14 December 2002|work=BBC Sport|publisher=BBC|accessdate=3 February 2018}} The goal was scored by [[Simon Betts]]; it would be his only goal in Darlington colours. Darlington goalkeeper [[Michael Ingham (footballer)|Michael Ingham]] played in both the final match at Boothferry Park and the first match to be played at Hull City's new home (in [[Sunderland A. F. C.|Sunderland]] colours). Boothferry Park was also the scene of a [[rugby league]] international when it hosted the first [[The Ashes (rugby league)|Ashes series]] test of the [[1982 Kangaroo tour]] between [[Great Britain Lions|Great Britain]] and [[Australian Kangaroos|Australia]] on 30 October. The Aussies ran in eight [[Try|tries]] to nil in a 40–4 thrashing watched by a vocal crowd of 26,771. ===Rugby League=== Boothferry Park hosted nine top grade rugby league matches, including five internationals, from 1980–1985.[http://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/venues/boothferry-park/results.html Boothferry Park @ Rugby League Project] {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor=#bdb76b ! Test No. !! Date !! Result !! Attendance !! Notes |- |1 || 29 February 1980 || {{rl|ENG}} def. {{rl|WAL}} 26–9 || 7,557 || [[1980 European Rugby League Championship|1980]] [[European Rugby League Championship]] |- |2 || 18 March 1981 || {{rl|ENG}} def. {{rl|WAL}} 17–4 || 5,617 || [[1981 European Rugby League Championship|1981]] [[European Rugby League Championship]] |- |3 || 6 December 1981 || {{rl|GBR}} def. {{rl|FRA}} 37–0 || 13,173 || 1981 Great Britain vs France |- |4 || 30 October 1982 || {{rl|AUS}} def. {{rl|GBR}} 40–4 || 26,771 || [[1982 Kangaroo tour of Great Britain and France|1982]] [[The Ashes (rugby league)|Ashes series]] |- |5 || 6 March 1983 || {{rl|GBR}} def. {{rl|FRA}} 17–5 || 6,055 || 1983 Great Britain vs France |} Other than the five internationals, Boothferry Park also hosted a further five top grade rugby league games. {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor=#bdb76b ! Game No. !! Date !! Result !! Attendance !! Notes |- |1 || 3 April 1953 || {{leagueicon|Hull|16}} [[Hull F.C.]] vs {{leagueicon|Hull KR|16}} [[Hull Kingston Rovers]] || 27,670 || |- |2 || 5 October 1980 || {{leagueicon|Kiwis|16}} [[New Zealand Kiwis|New Zealand]] def. {{leagueicon|Hull|16}} [[Hull F.C.]] 33–10 || 15,945 || [[1980 New Zealand rugby league tour of Great Britain and France|1980]] [[List of New Zealand Kiwis matches|New Zealand Kiwis tour]] |- |3 || 27 October 1984 || {{leagueicon|Hull|16}} [[Hull F.C.]] def. {{leagueicon|Hull KR|16}} [[Hull Kingston Rovers]] 29–12 || 25,237 || [[1984 Yorkshire Cup|1984]] [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire Cup]] Final |- |4 || 5 January 1985 || {{leagueicon|Hull|16}} [[Hull F.C.]] def. {{leagueicon|Leeds|16}} [[Leeds Rhinos|Leeds]] 18–6 || 13,362 || [[1984–85 League Cup (rugby league)|1984–85]] [[League Cup (rugby league)|John Player Special Trophy]] Semi-final |- |5 || 26 January 1985 || {{leagueicon|Hull KR|16}} [[Hull Kingston Rovers]] def. {{leagueicon|Hull|16}} [[Hull F.C.]] 12–0 || 25,326 || [[1984–85 League Cup (rugby league)|1984–85]] [[League Cup (rugby league)|John Player Special Trophy]] Final |} {{-}} ===Demolition=== [[File:Boothferry been knocked down.JPG|thumb|left|200px|Boothferry Park being demolished in March 2008]] Demolition of the ground eventually started on 10 January 2008, over five years after the final game was played there, and was completed during March. The North Stand and the terracing on the South and East Stands were eventually demolished in January 2010 after years of vandalism and arson attacks. [[Humberside Fire and Rescue Service]] had to be called out nearly 100 times during 2009 to deal with the situation.{{cite web |url = http://www.thisishullandeastriding.co.uk/displayNode.jsp?nodeId=136730&command=displayContent&sourceNode=136541&contentPK=19506642&folderPk=79656&pNodeId=243835 |title = Soon all we'll have is ... memories |date = 10 January 2008 |accessdate = 10 January 2008 |publisher = This is Hull and East Riding.co.uk }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{cite web |url = http://www.thisishullandeastriding.co.uk/displayNode.jsp?nodeId=136730&command=displayContent&sourceNode=136541&contentPK=19670600&folderPk=79656&pNodeId=243835 |title = Sun Sets On Boothferry's South Stand |date = 26 January 2008 |accessdate = 28 January 2008 |publisher = This is Hull and East Riding.co.uk }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{cite web |url = http://www.hull.vitalfootball.co.uk/article.asp?a=95961 |title = Boothferry Park – It's Coming Down |accessdate =28 February 2008 |date = 10 January 2008 |work = Vital Hull |publisher = Vitalfootball.co.uk }} The six floodlights that had dominated the West Hull skyline were finally dismantled in early 2011. ==Records== The highest attendance before the new stand was built was 40,179 in 1948 when Hull City played [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] in the [[FA Cup]]. In 1949 55,019 witnessed the visit of [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]] when the height of the terracing was increased.{{cite book|last=Peterson|first=Mike|title=A Century of City|year=2005|publisher=Yore Publications|isbn=0-9547830-7-7|page=52}} The biggest Scoring Game came in a friendly Match in 1950. When Hull City played [[Nuneaton Town F.C.|Nuneaton Borough]] the score ended 8-6 to Hull City with the score having been 0-1 to Nuneaton Borough at halftime. == Nicknames == [[File:Boothferry park.JPG|thumb|right|200px|Boothferry Park from the car park with the "o" missing.]] The stadium became affectionately known by supporters as "Fer Ark" in its later days, due to the lack of finances for maintenance which meant that only those letters were illuminated on the large "booth'''FER'''ry p'''ARK'''" signage.[http://www.wsc.co.uk/content/view/964/38/ When Saturday Comes – The Half Decent Football Magazine – Hull on earth] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120522121521/http://www.wsc.co.uk/content/view/964/38/ |date=22 May 2012 }} Before this it had been known as "Bothferry Park" when one of the illuminated "O"s fell off.[http://www.soccerprint.co.uk/shop/hull-city/hull-city-b-othferry-park-t-shirt.html Soccerprint Football T Shirts – Hull City B'othferry Park T Shirt]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} It was also known simply as "BP". ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Boothferry Park}} *{{cite web |url=http://www.hullcityafc.premiumtv.co.uk/page/BoothferryPark/0,,10338,00.html |title=A History of Boothferry Park |publisher=Hull City A.F.C. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100213125529/http://www.hullcityafc.net/page/BoothferryPark/0%2C%2C10338%2C00.html |archivedate=13 February 2010 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }} *[http://www.worldstadia.com/stadium/england/boothferry_park/1877.php Boothferry Park on Worldstadia.com] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080619192241/http://www.ewwa.net/boothferry/ Demolition photographs] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110721165325/http://www.28dayslater.co.uk/forums/showthread.php?t=16732 More pictures of the ground] {{Hull City A.F.C.}} {{Sport in Hull}} revision.text:
{{short description|Blunt weapon}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2010}}
A '''club''' (also known as a '''cudgel''', '''baton''', '''truncheon''', '''cosh''', '''nightstick''', or '''bludgeon''') is among the simplest of all [[weapon]]s: a short staff or stick, usually made of [[wood]], wielded as a weapon<ref>{{cite EB1911|wstitle=Club|volume=6|page=564}}</ref> since prehistoric times. There are several examples of blunt-force trauma caused by clubs in the past, including at the site of [[Nataruk]] in Turkana, Kenya, described as the scene of a prehistoric conflict between bands of hunter-gatherers 10,000 years ago.<ref>{{Cite journal|title= Inter-group violence among early Holocene hunter-gatherers of West Turkana, Kenya|url= http://www.nature.com/doifinder/10.1038/nature16477|journal= Nature|pages= 394–398|volume= 529|issue= 7586|doi= 10.1038/nature16477|first= M. Mirazón|last= Lahr|first2= F.|last2= Rivera|first3= R. K.|last3= Power|first4= A.|last4= Mounier|first5= B.|last5= Copsey|first6= F.|last6= Crivellaro|first7= J. E.|last7= Edung|first8= J. M. Maillo|last8= Fernandez|first9= C.|last9= Kiarie|pmid=26791728|year=2016}}</ref> In popular culture, clubs are associated with primitive cultures, especially [[caveman|cavemen]].
Most clubs are small enough to be swung with one hand, although larger clubs may require the use of two to be effective. Various specialized clubs are used in [[martial arts]] and other fields, including the [[club (law enforcement)|law-enforcement baton]]. The military [[mace (bludgeon)|mace]] is a more sophisticated descendant of the club, typically made of metal and featuring a spiked, knobbed, or flanged head attached to a shaft.
The wounds inflicted by a club are generally known as ''bludgeoning'' or ''[[blunt trauma|blunt-force trauma]]'' injuries.
==Law enforcement== {{Main|Baton (law enforcement)}} [[Police]] forces and their predecessors have traditionally favored the use, whenever possible, of [[less-lethal weapon]]s than guns or blades. Until recent times, when alternatives such as [[taser]]s and [[capsicum spray]] became available, this category of policing weapon has generally been filled by some form of wooden club variously termed a truncheon, baton, nightstick, or [[lathi khela|lathi]]. Short, flexible clubs are also often used, especially by plainclothes officers who need to avoid notice. These are known colloquially as blackjacks, saps, or coshes. They are also used in olden ages of the Philippines to punish citizens.
Conversely, criminals have been known to arm themselves with an array of homemade or improvised clubs, generally of easily concealable sizes, or which can be explained as being carried for legitimate purposes (such as [[baseball bat]]s).
In addition, [[Shaolin Monastery|Shaolin monks]] and members of other religious orders around the world have employed cudgels from time to time as defensive weapons.
==Types== Though perhaps the simplest of all weapons, there are many varieties of club, including: :''For other types see [[Baton (law enforcement)]].'' *'''[[Aklys]]''' – a club with an integrated leather thong, used to return it to the hand after snapping it at an opponent. Used by the legions of the [[Roman Empire]]. *'''Ball club''' – These clubs were used by the Native Americans. There are two types; the stone ball clubs that were used mostly by early Plains, Plateau and Southwest Native Indians and the wooden ball clubs that the Huron and Iroquois tribes used. These consisted of a relatively free-moving head of rounded stone or wood attached to a wooden handle. *'''Baseball, cricket and T-ball bats''' – The [[baseball bat]] is often used as an improvised weapon, much like the [[pickaxe handle]]. In countries where baseball is not commonly played, baseball bats are often first thought of as weapons (e.g. in Poland, baseball bats or similar are defined as weapons by law, so have been illegal to carry or possess).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://isap.sejm.gov.pl/Download?id=WDU19990530549&type=3 |title=Act of Weapons and Munition (polish only) Art.4.1.4a "(weapon is) club made of wood or other heavy and hard material, imitating a baseball bat"|publisher=isap.sejm.gov.pl (Polish Gov. Site) |date= |accessdate=2012-08-22}}</ref> [[Tee ball]] bats are also used in this manner. Their smaller size and lighter weight make the bat easier to handle in one hand than a baseball bat. *'''[[Baton (law enforcement)|Baton]]''' *'''Blackjack''': see '''''cosh'''''. *'''Clava''' (full name ''clava mere okewa'') – a traditional stone hand-club used by [[Mapuche]] Indians in Chile, featuring a long flat body. In Spanish, it is known as ''clava cefalomorfa''. It has some ritual importance as a special sign of distinction carried by the tribal chief.<ref>[http://chileprecolombino.cl/coleccion/clava-cefalomorfa/ Image of ''clava cefalomorfa''] {{webarchive|url=http://archive.wikiwix.com/cache/20140314081208/http://chileprecolombino.cl/coleccion/clava-cefalomorfa/ |date=2014-03-14 }} Museo Chileno de Arte Precolombino</ref> *'''Cosh''': *# A weapon made of covered metal similar to a blackjack. See [[Baton (law enforcement)#Blackjack|Blackjack]]. *# Any of various sorts of [[blunt instrument]] such as [[Bludgeon (weapon)|bludgeon]], [[Baton (law enforcement)|truncheon]] or the like.<ref>1991 edition of [[Chambers's Dictionary]]</ref> *'''Cudgel''' – A stout stick carried by peasants during the Middle Ages. It functioned as a walking staff and a weapon for both self-defence and wartime. Regiments of [[clubmen]] were raised as late as the [[English Civil War]]. The cudgel is also known as the [[singlestick]]. *'''[[Crowbar (tool)|Crowbar]]''' – The crowbar is a commonly used improvised weapon, though some examples are too large to be wielded with a single hand, and therefore should be classified as [[wikt:staff|staves]]. *'''[[Flashlight]]''' – A large metal flashlight, such as a [[Maglite]], can make a very effective improvised club. Though not specifically classified as a weapon, it is often carried for self-defense by security guards, bouncers and civilians, especially in countries where carrying weapons is restricted. *'''[[Gunstock war club]]''' – The wooden stocks of [[muskets|firearms]] introduced during the [[European colonization of the Americas]] were reportedly re-used by [[First Nations]] as improvised weapons; other sources claim that the club was an indigenous weapon before European contact, and acquired the term ''gunstock'' from the similarity of its shape. Regardless, the [[stock (firearm)|gunstock]] is an essential part of firearms, but it was stylized as a war club made famous by the American Indians as the [[gunstock war club]]. Another more modern variation of this kind of war club is the combat skill of [[bayonet]] usage. Even without a knife or blade type attachment, the rifle's body itself is used for [[close combat|close-quarters combat]] (CQC). *'''[[Jutte]]''' – One of the more distinctive weapons of the [[samurai]] police was the [[jutte (weapon)|jutte]]. Basically an iron rod, the jutte was popular because it could parry and disarm a sword-wielding assailant without serious injury. A single hook on the side near the handle allowed the jutte to be used for trapping or even breaking the blades of edged weapons, as well as for jabbing and striking. The hook could also be used to entangle the clothes or fingers of an opponent. Thus, feudal Japanese police used the jutte to disarm and arrest subjects without serious bloodshed. Eventually, the jutte also came to be considered a symbol of official status.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.e-budokai.com/hibuki/jutte.htm |title=Jutte |publisher=E-budokai.com |date= |accessdate=2008-12-26}}</ref> *'''[[Kanabō]]''' (nyoibo, konsaibo, tetsubō, ararebo) – Various types of different-sized Japanese clubs made of wood and or iron, usually with iron spikes or studs. First used by the [[Samurai]].<ref>''Tuttle dictionary of the martial arts of Korea, China & Japan'' – Page 168 Daniel Kogan, Sun-Jin Kim – 1996</ref><ref>''Pauley's Guide – A Dictionary of Japanese Martial Arts and Culture'' – Page 90 Daniel C. Pauley – 2009</ref><ref>Classical weaponry of Japan: special weapons and tactics of the ... – Page 91 Serge Mol – 2003</ref><ref>Secrets of the samurai: a survey of the martial arts of feudal Japan By Oscar Ratti, Adele Westbrook p.305</ref> *'''''Kiyoga''''', a spring baton similar in concept to the Asp collapsible police baton, but with the center section made of a heavy duty steel spring. The tip and first section slide into the spring, and the whole nests into a seven-inch handle. To deploy the kiyoga, all that is necessary is to grasp the handle and swing. This causes the parts to extend from the handle into a baton seventeen inches long. The kiyoga has one advantage over a conventional collapsible baton: it can reach around a raised arm trying to block it to strike the head.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.awma.com/productdetail/1280-spring-baton.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-02-08 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211084413/https://www.awma.com/productdetail/1280-spring-baton.asp |archivedate=2017-02-11 |df= }}. Retrieved February 7, 2017.</ref><ref>Francis, Dick. Straight (New York: G.P Putnam's Sons), 1989, pages 99 - 100 and 309.</ref> *'''[[Knobkierrie]]''', occasionally spelled ''knopkierie'' or ''knobkerry'', is a strong, short wooden club with a heavy rounded knob or head on one end, traditionally used by [[Southern Africa]]n ethnic groups including the [[Zulu people|Zulu]], as a weapon in warfare and the chase. The word ''knobkierrie'' derives from the [[Dutch language|Dutch]] ''knop'' (knob or button), and the [[Khoisan languages|Bushman and Hottentot]] ''kerrie'' or ''kirri'' (stick); in the Zulu language it was called the ''[[iwisa]]''. The weapon is employed at close quarters, or as a missile, and in time of peace may serve as a walking-stick. The head, or knob, is often ornately carved with faces or shapes that have symbolic meaning. The knobkierrie itself serves this function in the crest of the [[coat of Arms of South Africa]]. The name has been extended to similar weapons used by the natives of Australia, the Pacific islands and other places. *[[Kubotan]] – a short, thin, lightweight club often used by law enforcement officers, generally to apply pressure against selected points of the body in order to encourage compliance without inflicting injury. *[[Leangle (weapon)|Leangle]] An Australian Aboriginal fighting club with a hooked striking head, typically nearly at right angles to the weapon's shaft. The name comes from [[Kulin]] languages such as [[Wemba-Wemba]] and [[Woiwurrung]], based on the word ''lia'' (tooth).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/leangle|title=leangle - Definition of leangle in English by Oxford Dictionaries|author=|date=|website=Oxford Dictionaries - English|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170823205631/https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/leangle|archivedate=2017-08-23|df=}}</ref> *'''Life preserver''' (also [[hyphen]]ated '''life-preserver''') – a short, often weighted club intended for self-defense. Mentioned in Gilbert and Sullivan's ''[[The Pirates of Penzance]]'' and several [[Sherlock Holmes]] stories.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://sherlockholmes.stanford.edu/2007/notes9_1.html |title=Notes on the Sherlock Holmes story ''The Bruce Partington Plans'' |publisher=Sherlockholmes.stanford.edu |date=1908-12-12 |accessdate=2011-12-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111226072738/http://sherlockholmes.stanford.edu/2007/notes9_1.html |archivedate=2011-12-26 |df= }}</ref> *Lil Lil - An aboriginal club with boomerang like [[aerodynamics]]. Can be thrown or hand held. *'''[[Mace (bludgeon)|Mace]]''' – a metal club with a heavy head on the end, designed to deliver very powerful blows. The head of a mace may also have small studs forged into it. The mace is often confused with the spiked [[Morning star (weapon)|morning star]]. *'''[[Mere (weapon)|Mere]]''' – a type of short, broad-bladed club ([[patu]]), usually made from [[Nephrite jade]] ([[Pounamu]] or greenstone). A mere is one of the traditional, [[close combat]], one-handed [[weapon]]s of the indigenous [[Māori people|Māori]] of New Zealand. The designed use of the mere for forward striking thrusts is an unusual characteristic of Maori patu, whereas in other parts of the world, clubs are generally wielded with an ax-like downward blow.<ref name="hiroa">{{cite book | first=Te Rangi | last=Hiroa |authorlink=Te Rangi Hīroa| year=1949 | title=The Coming of the Maori | url= http://www.nzetc.org/tm/scholarly/tei-BucTheC-t1-g1-t2-body1-d12-d6.html#BucTheC-fig-BucTheC279a|pages=Short Clubs, 278–280 }}</ref> *'''[[Morning star (weapon)|Morning star]]''' - a medieval club-like weapon consisting of a shaft with an attached ball adorned with one or more spikes. *'''Nulla-nulla''' – a short, curved hardwood club, used as a hunting weapon and in tribal in-fighting, by the Aboriginal people of Australia. *'''[[Nunchaku]]''' (also called ''nunchucks'') – an Asian weapon consisting of two clubs, connected by a short rope, thong or chain, and usually used with one club in hand and the other swung as a [[flail (weapon)]]. *'''{{Interlanguage link multi|Oslop|ru|3=Ослоп}}''' – a two-handed, very heavy, often iron-shod, Russian club that was used as the cheapest and the most readily available infantry weapon. *Paddle Club - Common in the [[Solomon Islands]] these clubs could be used in warfare or for propelling a small dugout canoe<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.new-guinea-tribal-arts.com/tribal-war-clubs/|title=Tribal War Clubs {{!}} sell Tribal War Clubs {{!}} melanesian War Clubs|date=2018-04-12|work=new guinea tribal arts|access-date=2018-11-15|language=en-US}}</ref> *'''Pickaxe handle''' – [[Pickaxe]]s were common tools in the United States in the early 20th century, and replacement handles were widely available. In developing countries, where manual labor is still prevalent, it is pervasive. Strong and heavy, they make a formidable club and have often been used as club weapons. Pickaxe handles were handed out by segregationist [[Lester Maddox]] to the white patrons of his Pickrick Restaurant to keep that establishment from being "integrated". In the [[British Army]] pickaxe handles are or were officially used as guards' batons. *'''[[Rungu (weapon)|Rungu]]''' ([[Swahili language|Swahili]], plural ''marungu'') – a wooden throwing club or baton bearing special symbolism and significance in certain [[East Africa]]n tribal cultures. It is especially associated with [[Maasai people|Maasai]] [[morans]] (male warriors) who have traditionally used it in warfare and for hunting. *'''Sally rod''' – A Sally [[Switch (rod)|rod]] is a long, thin wooden stick, generally made from [[willow]] (Latin ''salix''), and used chiefly in the past in Ireland as a disciplinary implement, but also sometimes used like a club (without the fencing-like technique of [[stick fighting]]) in fights and brawls. In Japan this type of stick is called the [[Hanbō]] meaning half stick, and in FMA (Filipino martial arts) it is called the [[eskrima]] or [[escrima]] stick, often made from [[rattan]]. *'''Shillelagh''' – A [[shillelagh (club)|shillelagh]] is a wooden club or cudgel, typically made from a stout knotty stick with a large knob on the end, that is associated with Ireland in folklore. Shillelaghs have traditionally been made from oak, holly, or more famously blackthorn. It is surmised that the name of the weapon came from Shillelagh Forest in County Wicklow, Ireland. It is also known as a ‘bata’. Shillelaghs are almost exclusively made from blackthorn today. Whether made as a club, a walking stick, or a combination of the two, the stickmaker will generally pull up a sapling and carve the head out of the root ball, with the trunk serving as the shaft. A large branch with a section of the trunk has also been used. A properly made shillelagh can take up to two years to make, which includes curing time. *'''[[Slapjack (weapon)|Slapjack]]''' – This is a variation of the [[blackjack (weapon)|blackjack]]. It consists of a longer strap which lets it be used [[Flail (weapon)|flail]]-type, and can be used as a club or for trapping techniques as seen in the use of [[nunchaku]] and other flexible weapons. *'''Telescopic''' – [[Baton (law enforcement)#Expandable baton|Telescopic batons]] are rigid batons that are capable of collapsing to a shorter length for greater portability and concealability. They are illegal in the United Kingdom and some other countries. In Hungary these weapons are named ''vipera'' ("viper") and though officially illegal, they were reported as being repeatedly used by riot police units. *'''[[Tipstaff]]''' *'''[[Tonfa]]''' (also known in slang as a "[[Baton (law enforcement)#Side-handle baton|PR-24]]" or "Stanky Doodle") – a staff of Okinawan origin and featuring a second handle mounted perpendicular to the shaft *'''[[Totokia]]''' - traditional [[Fiji]]an weapon<ref name="Kjellgren">Eric Kjellgren, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=wkriAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA153 How to Read Oceanic Art]'' ([[Metropolitan Museum of Art]]/[[Yale University Press]], 2014), p. 153.</ref> *Ula - Traditional throwing club from Fiji<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.new-guinea-tribal-arts.com/fijian-war-clubs/|title=Fijian War clubs {{!}} Native weapons from Fiji {{!}} sell club {{!}} sell native weapon|date=2018-03-19|work=new guinea tribal arts|access-date=2018-11-15|language=en-US}}</ref> *U'u - A exquisitely carved ceremonial club from the [[Marquesas Islands|Marquesan Islands]] used as a chiefly status symbol<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.new-guinea-tribal-arts.com/polynesian-war-clubs/|title=Polynesian War clubs {{!}} war club {{!}} wooden club {{!}} tribal war club {{!}} sell club|date=2018-03-09|work=new guinea tribal arts|access-date=2018-11-15|language=en-US}}</ref>. *'''[[Waddy]]''' – a heavy hardwood club, used as a weapon for hunting and in tribal in-fighting, and also as a tool, by the Aboriginal people of Australia. The word ''waddy'' describes a club from New South Wales, but is also used generally by Australians to include other Aboriginal clubs, including the ''nulla nulla and'' ''leangle''.
==Animals using club-like appendages== *[[Club-winged manakin]] (bird) *[[Jamaican ibis]], extinct bird *[[Mantis shrimp]] *[[Rodrigues solitaire]], extinct bird with carpal spurs or knobs
==Gallery== <gallery> File:Ball-headed War Club with Spike, early 19th century, 50.67.61.jpg|''Ball-headed War Club with Spike'', Menominee (Native American), early 19th century, [[Brooklyn Museum]] File:Jutte 5.JPG|An iron [[jutte]] from Japan. File:Tetsubo.JPG| Small Japanese [[Tetsubo]], an iron club with a leather grip. File:Assorted shillelagh.JPG|Various assorted [[shillelagh (club)]]. File:Kataore, Mere pounamu (42cm x 12cm).jpg|Traditional Māori [[mere (weapon)|mere]], made from [[pounamu]] (nephrite jade). </gallery>

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=December 2009}} In many [[sport]]s, a '''competition number''' is used to identify and differentiate the competitors taking part in the competitive endeavour. For example, runners in a race may wear a prominent competition number so that they may be clearly identified from a distance. It is also called a '''bib number''' when worn on a [[Bib (garment)|bib]] over, or affixed to, the athlete's top.
==Vehicles== In [[motorsport]], competition numbers are attached to the vehicles taking part, also for identification. In some types of motorsport such as [[rallying|rallyes]], the competition number works in conjunction with special kinds of timing system (for example [[targa timing]]) and as a result numbers also usually relate to the competitors' [[due time]] and thus may exhibit gaps such as skipping from number 59 to number 100 (59 minutes to 1 hour due time).
==Athletics== Since the 2000s, [[track and field]] athletes at major competitions wear their names as well as their numbers on their bibs. In relay events, all team members have the [[IOC country code]]. [[Track event|Track]] athletes also wear a lane number on the shorts.
===Gallery=== <gallery> File:Olympic Games 1980 - 5000 m race.jpg|[[Athletics at the 1980 Summer Olympics – Men's 5000 metres|1980 Olympic 5000m]] Competition numbers on bibs File:Aselefech Mergia 6618.jpg| [[2009 World Championships in Athletics – Women's marathon|2009 World marathon]] Surname on front of bib File:3000 steeple final Berlin 2009.jpg | [[2009 World Championships in Athletics – Men's 3000 metres steeplechase|2009 World steeplechase]] Number on back of bib File:4 x 400 m Jamaica Berlin 2009.JPG| [[2009 World Championships in Athletics – Women's 4 × 400 metres relay|2009 World 4 × 400 m relay]] JAM for the Jamaican team </gallery>
==See also== *[[Number (sports)]] *[[Name (sports)]]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Competition Number}} [[Category:Numbering in sports|*]]

page.title: Dick Schaap Award for Outstanding Journalism

revision.comment: /* Dick Schaap Award Recipients */the work's name is "The New York Times"
revision.text:
{{refimprove|date=July 2011}} The '''Dick Schaap Award for Outstanding Journalism''' was established in 2002 to honor the memory of one of America's pre-eminent sports writers, [[Dick Schaap]]. The award is presented by the [[Nassau County Sports Commission]] and is given out to the journalist, in any medium, who best exemplifies the principles and talents of Dick Schaap during the past year. The award recipient is determined by confidential balloting of the Dick Schaap Selection Committee, which is composed of respected members of the media, and chaired by Dick's son, [[ESPN]] reporter [[Jeremy Schaap]].
Although the recipient need not be a [[sports journalism|sports journalist]], he/she must convey the passion and insight for stories and people he/she covers as Schaap did.
==Dick Schaap Award Recipients==
* 2002 - [[Jim McKay]], [[ABC Sports]] * 2003 - [[Frank Deford]], ''[[Sports Illustrated]]'' * 2004 - [[Bob Costas]], [[NBC]] & [[HBO]] Sports * 2005 - [[Dave Anderson (sportswriter)|Dave Anderson]], ''[[The New York Times]]'' * 2006 - [[Bob Ryan]], ''[[Boston Globe]]'' * 2007 - [[Lance Williams and Mark Fainaru-Wada]], ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' * 2008 - [[Mitch Albom]], ''[[Detroit Free Press]]'' * 2009 - No Recipient * 2010 - [[Mary Carillo]], [[NBC]] & [[HBO]] Sports * 2011 - [[Dave Kindred]], ''[[Golf Digest]]'' & [[National Sports Journalism Center]]
==External links== * http://www.dickschaapaward.org * http://www.nassausports.org
[[Category:American journalism awards]] [[Category:American sports trophies and awards]] [[Category:Sportscasting awards]] [[Category:Sports writing awards]]
{{US-journalist-stub}}

page.title: East and West Kent cricket teams

revision.comment: /* Matches */ oh, thats the wrong link then...
revision.text:
'''East Kent''' and '''West Kent''' were titles sometimes given to two [[cricket]] teams from their respective areas of the [[English county]] of [[Kent]] which generally played in matches prior to the foundation of the official [[Kent County Cricket Club]] in the mid 19th century. West Kent (or West of Kent) teams have been recorded from 1705 but there is no known record of an East Kent team until 1781. There were seven major matches from 1781 to 1790 in which teams of this type faced each other, although there is doubt about the match titles with sources using different team names.
The first Kent Cricket Club was founded in [[Canterbury]] on 6 August 1842, formed out of the [[Beverley Ground|Beverley Cricket Club]], and played its first match against [[All-England cricket teams|All-England]] three weeks later. In 1859 a second county club was formed at [[Maidstone]] to support the Canterbury club, the two often being known as the East Kent and West Kent clubs respectively.<ref name=wisden07>[[George Marsham|Marsham G]] (1907) [http://www.espncricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/150186.html A short history of Kent cricket], ''[[Wisden Cricketers' Almanack]]'', 1907. Retrieved 2018-03-06.</ref><ref name=khistory>[http://www.kentcricket.co.uk/the-club/history/ Kent County Cricket Club Timeline], [[Kent County Cricket Club]]. Retrieved 2017-11-23.</ref><ref name=kcht1>[https://kentcricketheritagetrust.wordpress.com/2017/04/13/the-history-of-kent-cricket/ The history of Kent Cricket: Part 1 – Prehistory], Kent Cricket Heritage Trust. Retrieved 2017-12-01.</ref><ref name=kcht2>[https://kentcricketheritagetrust.wordpress.com/2017/04/17/the-history-of-kent-cricket-part-two-lord-harris-takes-charge/ The history of Kent cricket Part Two - Lord Harris takes charge], Kent Cricket Heritage Trust. Retrieved 2018-02-15.</ref> The two clubs amalgamated in 1870 to form the modern day Kent County Cricket Club.<ref name=wisden07 /><ref name=khistory /><ref name=cihistory>[http://www.espncricinfo.com/kent/content/story/261949.html A brief history of Kent], [[CricInfo]]. Retrieved 2016-02-14.</ref>
Teams called East Kent and West Kent played each other twice in 1856 in minor matches. Those two matches are the last known to involve an East Kent team. West Kent became the name of a 19th-century club which played minor cricket only and was for a long time based at [[Chislehurst Cricket Club]], with which it ultimately amalgamated in 1980 as the Chislehurst and West Kent Cricket Club.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.chislehurst-cc.co.uk/CWKCC-Info/History.aspx |title=CWKCC History |publisher=Chislehurst and West Kent Cricket Club |accessdate=2009-06-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100310090324/http://www.chislehurst-cc.co.uk/CWKCC-Info/History.aspx |archivedate=2010-03-10 |df= }}</ref>
==Matches== The earliest known record of a "West Kent" or "West of Kent" team is in a match against [[Chatham Cricket Club]] on 7 August 1705, played at a place called "Maulden" in the primary source. There is no such place although it is generally believed to refer to [[Old County Ground|Town Malling]] near [[Maidstone]].<ref name=tmcc26may18>Town Malling Cricket Club [TownMallingCC] [https://twitter.com/TownMallingCC/status/1000304835722346496 The Old County Ground in @west_malling #westmalling 191yrs of cricketing history in The Garden Of England @VisitKent @westmallingCEP @west_mallingpc #KentDay], (Tweet), via [[Twitter]], 2018-05-26. Retrieved 2018-05-26.</ref><ref name=tmcc>[http://townmallingcc.play-cricket.com/website/articles/1614 300 Years of Cricket at Town Malling], Town Malling Cricket Club. Retrieved 2017-12-13.</ref><ref name=kl24apr17>Read C (2017) [http://www.kent-life.co.uk/out-about/places/10-reasons-you-should-visit-west-malling-1-4987925 10 reasons you should visit West Malling], ''Kent Life'', 2017-04-24. Retrieved 2017-12-12.</ref><ref name=IM7>[[Ian Maun|Maun I]] (2009) ''From Commons to Lord's, Volume One: 1700 to 1750'', p. 7. Cambridge: Roger Heavens. {{isbn|978-1-900-59252-9}}.</ref><ref name=khistory /> The result and details of the teams are unknown.<ref>Waghorn, p. 4.</ref> The next mention is a match on 22 September 1769, played at [[Vine Cricket Ground|Sevenoaks Vine]] between West Kent and [[Surrey county cricket teams|a Surrey team]]. The original report merely states that the [[wicket]]s will be "pitched soon after 10".<ref>Buckley, p. 52.</ref>
The earliest known match involving an "East Kent" team is one played against West Kent at Sevenoaks Vine on 20 and 21 June 1781. The question of nomenclature arises here because, with at least three "given men" (i.e., borrowed players), on each side the match is also called [[Duke of Dorset's XI cricket team|Duke of Dorset's XI]] versus [[Sir Horatio Mann's XI cricket team|Sir Horatio Mann's XI]] after the two team patrons [[John Sackville, 3rd Duke of Dorset]] and [[Sir Horatio Mann, 2nd Baronet|Sir Horatio (Horace) Mann]]. The "East Kent" team, Mann's XI, included [[John Small (cricketer)|John Small]], [[Richard Aubrey Veck]] and [[Lamborn (Hambledon cricketer)|Lamborn]] of [[Hambledon Club|Hambledon]] and [[Hampshire county cricket teams|Hampshire]]. The "West Kent" team, Dorset's XI, featured the Hambledon players [[Noah Mann]] and [[Tom Sueter]] with the [[Chertsey Cricket Club|Chertsey]] and Surrey players [[William Bedster]] and [[Lumpy Stevens]]. Noted Kent players involved in the match include [[Joseph Miller (cricketer)|Joseph Miller]], [[William Bullen]], [[William Bowra]], [[Robert Clifford (cricketer)|Robert Clifford]] and [[Thomas Pattenden]].<ref>Haygarth, pp. 47–48.</ref> Sevenoaks Vine was Dorset's home ground and there was a return match at [[Bourne Paddock]] at Mann's [[Bourne Park House]] near [[Bishopsbourne]] from 8 to 11 August. This also featured guest players with Surrey's [[William Yalden]] and Hampshire's [[James Aylward (cricketer)|James Aylward]] joining Small, Lamborn, Sueter, Bedster, Mann and Stevens.<ref name="Haygarth, pp. 49–50">Haygarth, pp. 49–50.</ref> Dorset's West Kent XI won both matches, the first by 10 wickets and the return by 106 runs.
Part of the confusion around match titles comes from the ways in which [[Arthur Haygarth]] records matches. He calls the June match "West Kent with Mann, Sueter & Lumpy versus East Kent with Small, Veck & Lamborn", but then calls the August match "Sir Horace Mann's Side versus the Duke of Dorset's Side". In its "Important Cricket Matches" guide, the [[Association of Cricket Statisticians and Historians]] follows Haygarth by using the abbreviated titles "East Kent with 3 gm v West Kent with 3 gm" for the June match and "Duke of Dorset v Sir H. Mann" for the August match ("gm" meaning "given men").<ref name=ACS25>ACS, p. 25.</ref>
On 25 and 26 June 1783, a match at Sevenoaks Vine involved "West Kent with [[David Harris (English cricketer)|Harris]], Stevens and Bedster versus East Kent". East Kent won this by 2 wickets. A curious condition of the match was that Lumpy Stevens, generally reckoned the outstanding bowler of the time, "was not to bowl, by agreement". This would have severely handicapped his team, which lost the match, as he was not a good batsman and so, as Haygarth says, "not much use as a given man". [[Stephen Amherst]], who was a [[Maidstone]] man and the patron of later West Kent teams, played in this match for the East.<ref>Haygarth, pp. 56–57.</ref>
Amherst had become a match organiser by the start of the 1789 season and led his team to a five-wicket victory against that of Mann at Coxheath on 22 and 23 May. A contemporary report in the ''Maidstone Journal'' describes the game as "Sir H. Mann with a select eleven of the County against S. Amherst, Esq. and the County at large, for 100 [[guinea (British coin)|guineas]]".<ref>Buckley, p. 135.</ref> The ACS calls the match "Sir H. Mann v S. Amherst".<ref name=ACS27>ACS, p. 27.</ref> However, the next Mann-Amherst match on 29 and 30 June, also at Coxheath, is called "East Kent v West Kent with each side having 4 gm".<ref name=ACS27/> This follows Haygarth, whose title is "East Kent with Boorman and Four of Hampshire versus West Kent with Four of Surrey". East Kent won by 8 runs and Haygarth confirms Mann and Amherst as respective managers.<ref name="Haygarth, pp. 49–50"/> The guest players in this match were [[John Boorman (cricketer)|John Boorman]], [[Richard Purchase]], John Small, David Harris and [[Thomas Taylor (cricketer)|Tom Taylor]] for the East and [[Billy Beldham]], [[Harry Walker (cricketer)|Harry Walker]], [[Tom Walker (cricketer)|Tom Walker]] and [[John Wells (cricketer)|John Wells]] for the West. Apart from a couple of changes in the East Kent lineup, the same teams met again at Coxheath on 4 and 5 August, East Kent winning by 57 runs.<ref>Haygarth, p. 96.</ref>
The final match between Amherst's West and Mann's East took place at Bishopsbourne from 7 to 11 September 1790. Haygarth called it "East Kent with Purchase versus West Kent". West Kent won by 130 runs.<ref>Haygarth, pp. 108–109.</ref> Sir Horatio Mann became [[Member of parliament|MP]] for [[Sandwich (UK Parliament constituency)|Sandwich]] in 1790 and reduced his involvement in cricket. The match in September 1790 is the last East Kent v. West Kent match that can be considered a major fixture.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Bibliography== * {{cite book |last=ACS |first= |authorlink=Association of Cricket Statisticians and Historians |title=A Guide to Important Cricket Matches Played in the British Isles 1709 – 1863|year=1981 |publisher=ACS |location=Nottingham |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Buckley |first=G. B. |authorlink=G. B. Buckley |title=Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket |year=1935 |publisher=Cotterell |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Haygarth |first=Arthur |authorlink=Arthur Haygarth |title=Scores & Biographies, Volume 1 (1744–1826) |year=1862 |publisher=Lillywhite |isbn=}} * {{cite book |last=Waghorn |first=H. T. |authorlink=H. T. Waghorn |title=The Dawn of Cricket |year=1906 |publisher=Electric Press |isbn=}}

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.4beta) ([[User:Josve05a|Josve05a]])
revision.text:
{{For|the New Testament biblical verse|John 3}} [[File:John 3 7.png|thumb|The ''JOHN 3:7 sign''. "Do not marvel that I said to you, ‘You must be born again.’"|250px]] A sign with the legend "'''JOHN 3:7'''" is often seen at [[Gaelic games]] stadiums in [[Ireland]]. It refers to a verse in the [[Gospel of John]] and for at least two decades has been displayed by fan Frank Hogan during matches.
The sign featured in the national media following its second disappearance in August 2009: Hogan launched an extensive, and ultimately successful, media campaign for its return before the next match. During that brief disappearance, bookmakers offered odds as to where it might next reappear and [[Paddy Power]] offered to purchase a replacement. The sign is so recognisable that, according to Hogan, "everybody wants to steal it or buy it. People regard it as a trophy."<ref name="Fan on a mission for lost biblical billboard"/> However, this recognition would also make it difficult for anyone else to display the sign in the event of its theft.<ref name="Fan on a mission for lost biblical billboard"/>
==Verse== [[John 3:7|The seventh verse of the third chapter]] of the [[Gospel of John]] reads, "Do not marvel that I said to you, ‘You must be born again.’"
==Symbolism== Hogan, originally from [[County Tipperary]], but living in [[County Limerick]],<ref name="Garda station hot favourite for return of sign"/><ref name="Seek and ye will find missing banner"/> carries the John 3:7 sign as "a reminder that [[Jesus]] died for the sins of man".<ref name="Fan on a mission for lost biblical billboard"/> Hogan originally had a sign which read "[[John 3:16]]" but changed this to the well known JOHN 3:7 after the Michael Jackson concert in Cork in 1988.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishnewsarchive.com/A-President-goes-AWOL.html |title=A President goes AWOL |newspaper=[[Nenagh Guardian]] |date=2000-07-08 }}{{dead link|date=April 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==History== Some time after Hogan started bringing the sign to the GAA games, Shane O'Brien started taking it to various events around Ireland like the Rose of Tralee, Galway Races, Cork Jazz Festival etc.... After doing this for a while he started recruiting a team to work with him on the streets at these festivals, and at weekends in Dublin. Some of this team also bring signs to GAA games to which Hogan can't make it. Since 2008, with the help of Philip Thompson, other teams have been formed in cities across Ireland and Britain. They just stand there on the streets with the signs ready to talk with anyone who stops to ask. Hogan said, "People ask me what it means and I can tell them because they have asked."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2000/0821/00082100047.html|title=Evangelist uses football to spread gospel message|newspaper=The Irish Times|date=2000-08-08|accessdate=2011-11-07}}</ref>
In June 2010, Hogan was banned from displaying the sign in Croke Park. However, stadium director Peter McKenna claimed this was a mistake and that Hogan and the sign would be welcome in Croke Park any time.<ref>{{cite news|first=Allison |last=Bray |url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/banned-biblical-banner-back-to-croker-2238268.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120903221056/http://www.independent.ie/national-news/banned-biblical-banner-back-to-croker-2238268.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-09-03 |title=Banned biblical banner back to Croker |newspaper=[[Irish Independent]] |date=2010-06-29 |accessdate=2010-06-29 }}</ref>
===Disappearances=== The sign was first tossed from a train window by some fanatical supporters.<ref name="Fan on a mission for lost biblical billboard"/> Hogan reported the sign missing again after a train journey which he undertook to return home from the [[All-Ireland Senior Football Championship 2009|All-Ireland Senior Football Championship]] quarter-final between [[Kildare GAA|Kildare]] and [[Tyrone GAA|Tyrone]] at [[Croke Park]], [[Dublin]] on 2 August 2009.<ref name="Fan on a mission for lost biblical billboard"/> Hogan had placed the billboard between carriages,<ref name="Garda station hot favourite for return of sign"/> and he first feared it had been stolen when "a lot of fellows got off and I discovered my sign was missing" as the train passed through [[Kildare]].<ref name="Fan on a mission for lost biblical billboard"/> After quizzing some of his fellow passengers, some suggested that there had been jokes about stealing the sign from some of those who had left the train.<ref name="Fan on a mission for lost biblical billboard"/> Hogan immediately contacted [[Garda Síochána|the Gardaí]] (police).<ref name="Fan on a mission for lost biblical billboard"/> CCTV footage of the train journey was viewed but the sign was not found.<ref name="Fan on a mission for lost biblical billboard">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/ireland/2009/0806/1224252080527.html|title=Fan on a mission for lost biblical billboard|newspaper=[[The Irish Times]]|date=2009-08-06|accessdate=2009-08-10}}</ref>
During its disappearance, bookmakers offered odds as to where it might next reappear, including such novelty bets as Gaelic games stadium Croke Park where it had last been displayed at a match, a [[Lap dance|lap dancing]] club, [[Dáil Éireann]], the music festival [[Oxegen]] in 2010, or at religious sites such as [[Knock, County Mayo|Knock]] in [[County Mayo]] and the holy tree stump of [[Rathkeale]] in [[County Limerick]].<ref name="Garda station hot favourite for return of sign"/> [[Paddy Power]] also offered to purchase a replacement.<ref name="Garda station hot favourite for return of sign">{{cite news|url=http://www.leinsterleader.ie/news/Garda-station-hot-favourite-for.5535013.jp |title=Garda station hot favourite for return of sign |newspaper=[[Leinster Leader]] |date=2009-08-07 |accessdate=2009-08-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090813011257/http://www.leinsterleader.ie/news/Garda-station-hot-favourite-for.5535013.jp |archivedate=2009-08-13 |df= }}</ref> The sign eventually turned up at Kildare Garda station in time for the [[All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship 2009|All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship]] semi-final between [[Limerick GAA|Limerick]] and [[Tipperary GAA|Tipperary]].<ref name="Seek and ye will find missing banner">{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/breakaway-uda-group-claims-to-have-decommissioned-guns-and-explosives-1855268.html|title=Seek and ye will find missing banner|newspaper=Irish Independent|date=2009-08-09|accessdate=2009-08-10}}</ref> After making contact with the ''[[Leinster Leader]]'' newspaper, Hogan had returned from Dublin following an appearance on ''[[The Marian Finucane Show]]'', when he was informed that the sign had been retrieved.<ref name="John 3:7 returned after tour of Kildare">{{cite news|first=Ruth |last=O'Brien |url=http://www.leinsterleader.ie/news/John-37-returned-after-tour.5546028.jp |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130218160501/http://www.leinsterleader.ie/news/John-37-returned-after-tour.5546028.jp |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-02-18 |title=John 3:7 returned after tour of Kildare |newspaper=Leinster Leader |date=2009-08-12 |accessdate=2009-08-16 }}</ref> It then emerged that the sign had spent an evening in a [[Kildare]] [[public house]] before embarking on a [[minibus]] journey to the south of the country via [[Kildangan]].<ref name="John 3:7 returned after tour of Kildare"/>
==Cultural references== At the [[2001 All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship Final]], Galway fans came up with their own sign, "EUGENE 2:11". This was in reference to Galway full-forward [[Eugene Cloonan]], who scored 2-11 in the semi-final against [[Kilkenny GAA|Kilkenny]] that same year.
On 1 November 2009, the Irish-language television channel [[TG4]] first aired a documentary about Frank Hogan and the JOHN 3:7 sign.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.limerickpost.ie/index.php/navigation-mainmenu-30/local-news/1151-frank-tells-it-as-it-is-in-tg4-documentary.html |title=Frank tells it as it is in TG4 documentary |newspaper=[[Limerick Post]] |date=2009-10-22 |accessdate=2011-11-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120403031159/http://www.limerickpost.ie/index.php/navigation-mainmenu-30/local-news/1151-frank-tells-it-as-it-is-in-tg4-documentary.html |archivedate=2012-04-03 |df= }}</ref>
[[John 3:16#Popular culture|Holding such signs]] is not unique to Ireland. It can be seen at many televised events in the United States. One famous practitioner in that country is the [[Rollen Stewart|Rainbow Man]].<ref name=straightdope>[http://www.straightdope.com/columns/read/457/whats-with-those-john-3 What's with those "John 3:16" signs] at ''[[The Straight Dope]]''. 23 January 1987.</ref>
A John 3:7 sign was present in the crowd during the Buffalo Bills historic comeback versus the Houston Oilers in a 1993 National Football League playoff game.

{{Infobox Prime Minister |honorific-prefix = [[The Right Honourable]] |name = Sir Lester Bird |honorific-suffix = [[Order of the National Hero (Antigua and Barbuda)|KNH]] |image = |imagesize = |order1 = |office1 = 2nd [[Prime Minister of Antigua and Barbuda]] |term_start1 = 9 March 1994 |term_end1 = 24 August 2004 |monarch1 = [[Elizabeth II]] |governor-general1 = [[James Carlisle]] |predecessor1 = [[Vere Bird]] |successor1 = [[Baldwin Spencer]] |birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1938|2|21}} |birth_place = [[New York City|New York]], [[New York (state)|New York]], United States |death_date = |death_place = |party = [[Antigua Labour Party|Labour]] |religion = |spouse = |children = |alma_mater = [[University of Michigan]] |profession = }}
'''Sir Lester Bryant Bird''', [[Order of the National Hero (Antigua and Barbuda)|KNH]] (born 21 February 1938) was the [[Prime Minister of Antigua and Barbuda#Prime Ministers of Antigua and Barbuda, 1981-present|second Prime Minister]] of [[Antigua and Barbuda]] from 1994 to 2004 and a well-known athlete. He was chairman of the [[Antigua Labour Party]] (ALP) from 1971 to 1983, then became Prime Minister when his father, [[Vere Bird|Sir Vere Bird]], the previous Prime Minister, resigned.
==Early life and education== Bird was born in [[New York City]] on 21 February 1938.<ref name="East">Roger East and Richard Thomas, "[https://books.google.com/books?id=Mz-fXRsedPMC Profiles of people in power: the world's government leaders]" (2003). Psychology Press, pp. 16-17.</ref> Lester and his elder brother [[Vere Bird Jr.]], also a British-educated lawyer, have been considered sometime rivals, with ''[[The New York Times]]'' writing in 1990 that Lester had always overshadowed his brother, according to those who have known them both.<ref name="French">Howard W. French, "[https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/16/world/island-s-hushed-scandals-unhushed.html Island's Hushed Scandals, Unhushed]", ''The New York Times'', June 16, 1990.</ref><ref name="Glass">Robert Glass, "Caribbean Island Focus of International Arms Scandal", Associated Press, May 14, 1990.</ref> He was educated at Antigua Grammar School and was brought up as a [[Methodism|Methodist]]. Bird was a [[cricket]] player in his youth, playing for the [[Leeward Islands]], and a [[long jump]] champion. He won a bronze medal in the long jump at the [[1959 Pan American Games]] in [[Chicago]] while representing the [[West Indies Federation|British West Indies]]. He attended the [[University of Michigan]], where he was [[All-American]] long jumper in 1960 and graduated in 1962.<ref name="French"/><ref name="Glass"/> Bird completed his study of law in Britain and was [[called to the bar]] at [[Gray's Inn]] in 1969. From 1969 to 1976, Bird engaged in private practice in Antigua.<ref name="East"/>
==Political career== Bird's political career began in 1971, when he was nominated to the [[Senate of Antigua and Barbuda|Senate]]. The frequently-dominant Antigua Labour Party was in opposition for a five-year period. Bird was named chairman of the ALP and the [[leader of the opposition]] in the Senate. Lester continued to served as leader of the opposition until he was elected to the [[House of Representatives of Antigua and Barbuda|House of Representatives]] at the 1976 elections, when the ALP returned to power.<ref name="East"/> Bird joined his father's government as Deputy Prime Minister. In addition to serving as Deputy Prime Minister, Bird also served as Minister of Economic Development, Tourism, and Energy. Bird's tenure as Minister of Tourism and Minister of Economic Development was controversial, and he personally benefited from tourism partnerships with foreign investors, including in the construction of the Royal Antiguan Hotel.<ref>Carolyn L. Cartier and Alan A. Lew, ''Seductions of place: geographical perspectives on globalization and touristed landscapes'' (2005). Psychology Press: p. 229.</ref>
Following independence in 1981, Bird gained the external affairs portfolio and was the first chairman of the Organization of Eastern Caribbean States in 1982. He was chairman of OECS for a second time in 1989.<ref name="East"/> The ALP government and Bird himself won [[Antigua and Barbuda general election, 1994|re-election in 1994]] and [[Antigua and Barbuda general election, 1999|1999]]. These elections, as well as the 1989 elections, were highly controversial; the 1989 elections were "marred by irregularities and fraud" and charges made by the opposition, described as credible by [[Freedom House]], that the ALP used bribery and intimidation and exerted undue influence over the elections supervisor.<ref name="Freedom House">[[Freedom House]], ''Freedom in the World: The Annual Survey of Political Rights & Civil Liberties, 1993-1994'' (1994). University Press of America, pp. 117-119.</ref> The 1999 was deemed nor free or fair in an independent report which concluded that the opposition [[United Progressive Party (Antigua and Barbuda)|United Progressive Party]] (UPP) could "conceivably could have won a majority of seats in parliament" if the election had been fair.<ref>[http://aceproject.org/ero-en/regions/americas/AG/Antigua%20and%20Barbuda%20-%20elctions%201999.pdf "The Failings of Governance in Antigua & Barbuda: The Elections of 1999"], June 1, 1999.</ref>
The ALP had been divided by a succession crisis between Lester Bird and Vere Bird, Jr., since 1989. Lester Bird lost his deputy prime minister post in 1991, but retained the external affairs ministry and the planning and trade portfolio. Sir Vere Bird was initially thought to have favoured Vere Jr. until an arms scandal in which the elder son had been found to have been involved in the smuggling of weapons from Antigua to the [[Colombia]]n [[Medellín Cartel]].<ref name="East"/><ref name="French"/><ref name="Freedom House"/> Vere Bird, Jr., then Minister of Public Works, was dismissed from office and an inquiry, led by [[Louis Blom-Cooper|Sir Louis Blom-Cooper]], [[Queen's Counsel|Q.C.]], recommended that he never be allowed to hold office again (although he subsequently did return to office), boosting Lester Bird's chances to follow his father in the prime ministership and defusing pressure for Vere Bird to step down.<ref name="East"/><ref name="French"/><ref name="Freedom House"/>
In 1992, another scandal, involving Sir Vere Bird's siphoning of public funds into a personal account, furthered calls for him to step down, with three opposition parties uniting to form the UPP under the leadership of [[Baldwin Spencer]]. Following a successful [[general strike]] called by the UPP, Sir Vere announced in March 1992 he would step down at the 1994 general elections.<ref name="East"/><ref name="Freedom House"/> The ALP succession crisis continued following this, with a special convention to elect a successor on May 24, 1992 resulting in a deadlock between Lester Bird and John St. Luce, the [[information minister]]. The ALP leadership question was finally settled at the party's September 1993 convention, at which Lester won the leadership of the party, defeating St Luce, 169 votes to 131. The party post of ALP chairman went to Vere Jr.<ref name="East"/><ref name="Freedom House"/>
In the [[Antigua and Barbuda general election, 1994|March 1994 elections]], the ALP under Bird's leadership won 11 out of 17 seats even as the opposition criticized the ALP over corruption issues. During the election the ALP pledged [[open government]], an [[ombudsman]] to deal with citizen complaints, and new jobs, especially in [[Economy of Antigua and Barbuda|tourism]]. Bird assumed the prime ministership on March 9, 1994.<ref name="East"/> He appointed St. Luce (but not his brother Vere Jr.) to the cabinet. (Vere Jr. was subsequently named special adviser). Lester Bird took the portfolios for external affairs, planning, [[social services]], and information for himself, and in a 1996 [[cabinet reshuffle]] also took the communications, [[civil aviation]], international transport, and [[Gambling|gaming]] portfolios.<ref name="East"/>
In the [[Antigua and Barbuda general election, 1994|1999 elections]], the ALP increased its parliamentary majority by one seat, holding 12 seats. Bird was reconfirmed as prime minister and elevated Vere Jr. to the cabinet as [[minister of agriculture]], marking his full [[political rehabilitation]]. Bird also shuffled his own portfolios and by December 2002 held the foreign affairs, finance, legal affairs, justice, and [[national security]] ministries in addition to being the prime minister.<ref name="East"/>
In the [[Antigua and Barbuda general election, 2004|March 2004 election]], the ALP was defeated by the [[United Progressive Party (Antigua and Barbuda)|United Progressive Party]] (UPP) led by [[Baldwin Spencer]]. Bird's party lost eight seats, and he himself was defeated by [[Errol Cort]], who became Minister of Finance in the new UPP government.
Bird remained the ALP's political leader following the party's 2004 defeat. He led the party in the [[Antigua and Barbuda general election, 2009|March 2009 election]]; although the ALP lost the election, it gained 3 seats from the UPP and Bird defeated Cort by 96 votes in the St John's Rural East constituency, where he had lost in 2004. He subsequently held the position of [[Leader of the Opposition|Leader of Her Majesty's Loyal Opposition]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.caribbeanelections.com/antigua/results/default.asp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-03-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091125051829/http://www.caribbeanelections.com/antigua/results/default.asp |archivedate=2009-11-25 |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.antiguasun.com/paper/?as=view&sun=281935077507132005&an=140029119612282007&ac=Columnist "Different parties similar woes - Reviewing the political affairs of 2007"], ''Antigua Sun'', December 28, 2007.</ref>
Bird was succeeded as ALP leader by [[Gaston Browne]] in 2012, who led the party to victory in [[Antigua and Barbuda general election, 2014|June 2014 general election]]. Bird won a seat and again defeated Errol Cort.<ref>Jacqueline Charles, [http://www.miamiherald.com/2014/06/13/4175779/antigua-prime-minister-baldwin.html "Browne becomes new prime minister of Antigua, youngest ever"], ''Miami Herald'', 13 June 2014.</ref>
In 2014, he was made a [[Order of the National Hero (Antigua and Barbuda)|Knight of the Order of the National Hero]] (KNH) by Antigua and Barbuda.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://antiguaobserver.com/sir-lester-bird-receives-abs-highest-national-honour/|title = Sir Lester Bird receives A&B’s highest national honour|date = 2014|accessdate = 10 January 2016|website = |publisher = The Daily Observer|last = |first = }}</ref>

[[Anderson University (Indiana)|Anderson University Ravens]] | capacity = 3000 | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} The '''O.C. Lewis Gymnasium''' is a 3000-seat multi-purpose [[arena]] in [[Anderson, Indiana]], [[United States|USA]] on the [[Anderson University (Indiana)|Anderson University]] campus. It hosts local [[sporting events]] and [[Gymkhana (equestrian)|gymkhana]]. It was home to the [[Indiana Alley Cats]], in 2005, and the [[Anderson University (Indiana)|Anderson University]] Ravens [[basketball]] teams. The arena opened in 1962. {{Anderson University (Indiana)}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Lewis Gymnasium}} [[Category:Basketball venues in Indiana]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Indiana]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Anderson, Indiana]] [[Category:Anderson Ravens and Lady Ravens]] [[Category:1962 establishments in Indiana]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1962]] {{Indiana-stadium-stub}}
